data.text: De Guindos: To avoid a two-speed recovery we need a pan-European fiscal response. We need to complete the EMU and have a genuine banking union, a single capital market and a common budgetary instrument 2/5

(THREAD) There is a lot of uncertainty around the euro area recovery, says ECB Vice-President Luis de Guindos to La Stampa. Most worrying is that a two-speed recovery seems to be emerging 1/5 https://t.co/L0DDFLURDH
Tune in at 17:00 CET today to watch Vice-President Luis de Guindos speak as part of @business_econ’s webinar series Perspectives on the Pandemic at https://t.co/X0Qx38fnTO https://t.co/HAJBZEAkYp

The ECB and the Eurosystem will join the expanded #BISInnovationHub. The new @BIS_org centres in Frankfurt and Paris, coordinated by the ECB, will bring their expertise in designing the future of digital banking and finance. https://t.co/GxpBwE09ww
Euro money market statistics (third maintenance period 2020) https://t.co/fQ0RA10qHH
Here is the correct link to the paper https://t.co/d76Rm8mPy1
Letter from the ECB President to Mr Sven Simon, MEP, on monetary policy https://t.co/cJ5fP2pjb6
Letter from the ECB President to Mr Nuno Melo, MEP, on monetary policy https://t.co/fAnMZrcgiY (EN) https://t.co/EDMGvpLQBF (PT)
Letter from the ECB President to Mr Piernicola Pedicini, MEP, on monetary policy https://t.co/9POsxmDKUx (EN) https://t.co/Nr4JK2ciVV (IT)

Labour, product and financial market regulations at national and EU level may need to be adapted for European countries to fully reap the benefits of digital technologies. Vulnerable groups such as those experiencing job insecurity and lower earnings should be safeguarded 6/6

The coronavirus pandemic may result in an acceleration of digitalisation, providing EU countries with an opportunity to catch up. This could lead to structural changes across economies, and possibly affect labour markets, growth and productivity 5/6

How digitalisation impacts inflation may differ at short and long horizons though. For example, more online competition may lead to lower prices in the short term, while increasing market concentration and profit margins can cause higher prices in the medium to long term 4/6

Digitalisation impacts the economy through a number of channels, including productivity, employment, wages and prices. It raises productivity and lowers prices, similar to other supply/tech shocks. This is relevant for monetary policy and its transmission 3/6

There are significant differences between countries in the EU in terms of the adoption of digital technologies, such as robotisation and online platforms, and in the size of the digital economy. Most EU countries are falling behind competitors, particularly the USA and Japan 2/6 https://t.co/cNmvaQwvqw

(Thread) How does digitalisation impact our economy? Why is it relevant for monetary policy? And how does Europe compare to competitors such as the USA? Find out in our latest Occasional Paper https://t.co/Vs7ha4yUys @RobertMAnderton @filpet4 1/6 https://t.co/8LTZhtDJEf

Without the PEPP, we would now be in the middle of a severe financial crisis, says Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel in a speech. The measures taken by the ECB are necessary, suitable and proportionate to ensure price stability in the euro area https://t.co/3N1OkI1nOi

Ohne das PEPP befänden wir uns heute inmitten einer schweren Finanzkrise, sagt EZB Direktoriumsmitglied @Isabel_Schnabel in einer Rede. Die Maßnahmen der EZB sind erforderlich, geeignet und verhältnismäßig, um Preisstabilität im Euroraum zu gewährleisten https://t.co/PM18xHiGvL

Watch again: Christine Lagarde speaking at the Northern Light Summit about how the recovery process will be transformational for some industries. The full recording of the event is available here https://t.co/YBGgQBv4X3 https://t.co/S1jh7f43JA
How did euro area bank lending and money supply evolve in May? How do they compare with April’s figures? Find out more in the press release https://t.co/27l0ms8BGg https://t.co/Emh72Rrikp

Coming up in 15 minutes: President Lagarde discusses the prospects for economic recovery from the coronavirus pandemic at the online Northern Light Summit. Follow the event live https://t.co/YBGgQBv4X3
Speech Yves Mersch: The World Economy Transformed https://t.co/F4syPoXBt2
Press release: ECB publishes Consolidated Banking Data for end-December 2019 https://t.co/ECTbjxfvwY

How is the coronavirus pandemic affecting bank lending decisions? ECB Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria discusses this with our host @MichaelSteen in a new episode of #TheECBPodcast https://t.co/ziMbZCS8El https://t.co/sahMbvvQNd
Press release: New Eurosystem repo facility to provide euro liquidity to non-euro area central banks https://t.co/LlkkWWpfW0
Letter from Andrea Enria, Chair of the Supervisory Board, to Mr Giegold, MEP, on banking supervision https://t.co/VMrXOqceUD
Speech Philip R. Lane: The ECB’s monetary policy response to the pandemic: liquidity, stabilisation and supporting the recovery https://t.co/5liOSgEEWj

Coming up at 09:00 CET: Chief Economist Philip R. Lane speaks about the ECB’s monetary policy response to the coronavirus pandemic at Frankfurt Main Finance (@FMFdigital). Register here to watch live https://t.co/8nGiFM9YgW https://t.co/I61oprLzkp

Enria: We view consolidation at the national level positively, but there should also be mergers at the cross-border level, making the European banking system more integrated https://t.co/VzhAXJa7ZW 4/4

Enria: The response to the crisis shows us that the rules that have been introduced since 2009 are working well. Their effect has certainly been positive. It is because of these rules that the banking system is now in a position to withstand a crisis of such proportions 3/4

Enria: European authorities have assured a rapid, effective and unified response to the state of emergency. The banking union is functioning, even if some aspects do not allow for a genuinely European response to the crisis 2/4

(THREAD) European banks are suffering from structural weakness and must improve their profitability and restore their ability to attract investors and generate capital, says ECB Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria to @sole24ore 1/4 https://t.co/0LAB8LO9d8

The coronavirus pandemic is the first test for the banking union and we have proven that we can deliver fast, says ECB Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria in #TheECBPodcast. Listen to the full episode with our host @MichaelSteen https://t.co/ziMbZCS8El https://t.co/g86SHa0MMM
Philip R. Lane discusses this and other elements of the PEPP in a @PrincetonBCF online webinar from 18:30 CET. Watch live here https://t.co/Gc4O4qi4vG

In a post on #TheECBBlog, Chief Economist Philip R. Lane discusses the market stabilisation role of the pandemic emergency purchase programme (PEPP). Read the post https://t.co/Ga17859lzC https://t.co/7mMAsD3GwM

De Guindos: The crisis has highlighted important weaknesses in the policy framework for non-banks. Accelerating progress towards the capital markets union remains a key priority https://t.co/ynI9VhGkgM 5/5
De Guindos: In the non-bank financial sector, decisive policy action helped stabilise financial markets and relieve  liquidity stress after the pandemic outbreak 4/5
De Guindos: Different national responses can lead to financial fragmentation, and the increase in public debt levels, while necessary today, needs to be managed in the medium term 3/5

De Guindos: Greater resilience has allowed banks to weather the initial shock of the crisis, and the policy measures taken are helping banks to continue lending to households and companies and to absorb losses 2/5
(THREAD) The financial sector will have an important role to play in the euro area recovery from the pandemic crisis, says ECB Vice-President Luis de Guindos 1/5 https://t.co/msYL6nyit9

Hakkarainen: To ensure the benefits of the banking union are preserved and to come out of the crisis stronger and more united, the EU should complete the banking union by 2024 https://t.co/E68T5p5ang 3/3

Hakkarainen: The institutional framework of European banking supervision has allowed a swift and decisive supervisory response to the coronavirus crisis. This will help banks play their part in softening the impact of the shock on the real economy 2/3

(THREAD) The banking union has already provided huge benefits to Europeans by increasing competition and levelling the playing field across borders, says ECB Supervisory Board member Pentti Hakkarainen 1/3 https://t.co/jkONM2kJcM

De Guindos: European banks are much more resilient than ten years ago, but they suffer from low profitability which the pandemic will exacerbate. Saving, reducing excess capacity, and consolidation will be unavoidable https://t.co/fbhaSaaSpZ 3/3
De Guindos: In the allocation of our pandemic emergency purchases we follow the capital key. We will use the flexibility the programme allows over time and across asset classes and countries 2/3

(THREAD) Speaking to Der Spiegel, ECB Vice-President Luis de Guindos says the ECB has expanded its bond purchases in the face of a severe economic crisis to promote growth, achieve its inflation aim and prevent fragmentation in the euro area 1/3 https://t.co/nBnVfUkcsr

The risk of infection via a banknote is therefore of no particular significance. The full results of our research will be made available following the conclusion of the studies.
 
Read about payments during the coronavirus crisis in our recent blog post https://t.co/IkAriPFCtf

Our research shows that the survival rate of the virus is 10 to 100 times higher on surfaces such as stainless steel than on our cotton banknotes. Porous surfaces, like those of euro banknotes, are also less likely to transfer the virus than smoother surfaces like plastic.

We regularly conduct research on the impact of banknotes on public health. Since the outbreak of the coronavirus pandemic, we’ve been working closely with labs to assess how the virus behaves on different surfaces. https://t.co/AhY4opXIua
Letter from the ECB President to Ms Clare Daly, MEP, on the Charter of Fundamental Rights https://t.co/ExY9juzJ32
Letter from the ECB President to Mr Domènec Ruiz Devesa and Mr Jonás Fernández, MEPs, on monetary policy https://t.co/oCmhmZgTKn

Letter from the ECB President to Mr Emmanouil Fragkos, MEP, on monetary policy https://t.co/GbKgSIMV4J (EN) https://t.co/TfyF8f4kGF (EL)
US dollar liquidity-providing operations from 1 July 2020 https://t.co/L5o4mUJfKM
Euro area monthly balance of payments (April 2020) https://t.co/G3rnDJQSZI

In the context of the #coronavirus pandemic, the GWI already pointed to clear signs of economic weakness as early as 2 March. Indeed it had increased sharply – much faster than in the 2008 crisis. At the time of writing the Bulletin, the GWI remained at a record high.

The Global Weakness Index (GWI) is a real-time measure of how weak the global economy is. The latest #ResearchBulletin proposes the indicator and assesses how it can help provide early warnings of a downturn that can be crucial for a fast policy response https://t.co/8h3sM60gWI https://t.co/8YgDBaUtl9

A strong European response is required to support the recovery and avoid economic fragmentation in the eurozone. First steps totalling up to €540 billion have been taken, our #EconomicBulletin shows. Nonetheless, further efforts at EU level are needed https://t.co/mP6Y4M8ONd https://t.co/jH1pwP46p1

What’s the impact of the coronavirus pandemic on trade in the service sector and on financial markets? What are the factors shaping people’s attitudes towards the ECB and the euro? Find out the answer to these questions in our latest #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/JxXykVpnpc https://t.co/tmM1VensiN

Short-time work and temporary lay-off schemes are being used in several euro area countries while #coronavirus lockdown measures are in place. Our latest #EconomicBulletin explores how these schemes are working in the five largest euro area countries https://t.co/tiQ4uc3OyR https://t.co/1ST5p9JxsH

Lockdown measures put in place to contain the #coronavirus pandemic are having a significant impact on euro area travel, with air traffic decreasing sharply. Find out how euro area countries that are reliant on travel and tourism are being affected https://t.co/qeqcr0J0ql https://t.co/b2XCfLz4M9
You can also see a summary of the ECB’s response to the coronavirus pandemic on our web page available in 23 EU languages https://t.co/HJzEtFpSSL

Measures taken by central banks and governments have contributed significantly to minimising the impact of the #coronavirus shock on financial markets. Read an analysis of investors’ risk aversion during the crisis in our latest #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/5mPPolY30o https://t.co/loerGbHngf
Andrea Enria: This will help safeguard the banking sector’s resilience, but can also drive a smoother and faster transition to a more sustainable economy https://t.co/tLSOzQpMAm 3/3
Andrea Enria: We expect banks to start taking action now. It is critical for them to start developing their capacity to manage climate-related and environmental risks 2/3

(THREAD) We want to ensure a resilient banking sector that manages climate-related and environmental risks, says ECB Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria at the ECB webinar on climate and environmental risks 1/3 https://t.co/n5D1Mcvsns
Working group on euro risk-free rates recommends voluntary compensation for legacy swaption contracts affected by the discounting transition to the €STR https://t.co/fMVxZTO6IX

Panetta on the #coronavirus shock: Those who write the history books might see it as a turning point – a key moment for Europe, when we all understood that addressing challenges together brings benefits to everyone. 
Read the interview https://t.co/qWgqTeE6cE 3/3

Panetta on the international role of the euro: The euro could and should have a bigger international role. This has not happened because the institutional framework of the eurozone is incomplete. We must complete it 2/3

(THREAD) Fiscal and monetary policies need to work hand in hand to bring the economy back on track as soon as possible, says ECB Executive Board member Fabio Panetta in an interview with @lemondefr. The European recovery fund should be deployed no later than early 2021 1/3 https://t.co/kTJz71RE76

Support for #EMU is closely linked to citizens’ perceptions of their personal financial situation and the overall economic situation, our #EconomicBulletin shows. Find out more on the factors shaping people’s attitudes towards the ECB and the #euro https://t.co/mKRxHph58P https://t.co/nTn6WPbh4X
Speech Christine Lagarde: The path out of uncertainty https://t.co/wN6zjrij7I
Find here our newly published annual review of the international role of the euro https://t.co/lqfJcD1GBx

Panetta: Through the right mix of fiscal and monetary policy, we can build a better functioning, more stable Monetary Union, in turn increasing the euro’s influence and the benefits that accrue to euro area members. Read the contribution https://t.co/apXWYEOQ8F 4/5

Panetta: The market segmentation of the euro area and a limited supply of perceived safe assets exacerbates the vulnerabilities caused by the absence of fiscal integration and limits the euro’s global standing 3/5

Panetta: The euro’s potential as a global currency has not been fully achieved, and not all countries have profited from the “privilege” of lower borrowing costs in global capital markets, especially in times of heightened risk aversion 2/5
(THREAD) The goals of boosting the euro’s global standing and sharing its advantages more evenly are one and the same, writes Executive Board member Fabio Panetta. 1/5 https://t.co/oMOdWWqq8m

Tune in today at 14:00 CET to watch ECB Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria participate in a moderated interview at the 24th Goldman Sachs Annual European Financials Conference at https://t.co/SYbjPKTyHV https://t.co/3IUplFTBCy

Andrea Enria: We have recently started carrying out a vulnerability assessment. The ECB will check if currently available capital buffers would be sufficient to cover the losses stemming from the adverse developments of the pandemic https://t.co/yCJazVgLiD 4/4

Andrea Enria: The ECB will strive to put in place a well-designed and credible path to normality, taking into account evidence on the severity of the shock, bank-specific circumstances, and the need to preserve the sector’s fundamental lending role to the real economy. 3/4

Andrea Enria: The use of capital and liquidity buffers during a sharp downturn is essential to prevent the banking sector from acting pro-cyclically and excessively restricting lending to preserve capital during a recession. 2/4

(THREAD) We are going through an unprecedented economic shock of a systemic nature, which will hopefully be temporary but is potentially damaging for banks’ balance sheets and the wider economy, says Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria. 1/4 https://t.co/KCLz9kTig2
Chief Economist Philip R. Lane spoke with @drivetimerte on the ECB’s measures in response to the coronavirus crisis. Listen back here https://t.co/R4xwGDrDSz
See a summary of the decisions we’ve taken to limit the economic fallout of the pandemic, now available on our new webpage in 23 EU languages https://t.co/tDtOp4gz59

What challenges does the coronavirus pandemic pose for banks? What role can they play in helping the economy deal with this crisis? Tune into the latest episode of #TheECBPodcast with ECB Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria and host @MichaelSteen https://t.co/ziMbZCAxfL https://t.co/xV0A7sssfh

Letter from Andrea Enria, Chair of the Supervisory Board, to Mr Urtasun, MEP, on national measures for the banking sector in the COVID-19 crisis https://t.co/EbTTP3PJUY (EN) https://t.co/BEbe73dB4Q (ES)
Letter from Andrea Enria, Chair of the Supervisory Board, to Dr Hollnagel, Member of the German Bundestag, on business model supervision https://t.co/Gi9Q6hdqnZ (EN) https://t.co/7ob1o3AvfI (DE)

De Guindos: Loan guarantees and relief measures taken by supervisors and macroprudential authorities should help the euro area banking system to sustain lending to households and companies, while weathering losses https://t.co/Qt2dr8TeP2 5/5

De Guindos: Banks’ low profitability remains a key challenge. Looking ahead, credit losses are expected to increase and overcapacity is weighing on profitability prospects. Structural changes and consolidation in the sector are necessary 4/5
De Guindos: Main concerns are low bank profitability and the increase in public debt levels in the medium-term, amid weaker growth prospects 3/5

De Guindos: The euro area financial system has weathered the immediate stress thanks to bold policy action and banks’ improved capital and liquidity positions. Yet medium-term risks have increased markedly 2/5

(THREAD) After a sharp contraction in the first half of 2020, economic recovery is expected to start in the second, says ECB Vice-President Luis de Guindos in the webinar of the Institute of International and European Affairs @IIEA 1/5 https://t.co/Dgok2Mke2z
Speech Isabel Schnabel: The ECB’s policy in the COVID-19 crisis – a medium-term perspective https://t.co/fEtuzAPzIS Slides https://t.co/tFlHapmdAN
Which criteria does a country need to fulfil to join the eurozone? Find out in our explainer https://t.co/CwUT4BannY https://t.co/2xzWjUuPYM
The report is available in 22 European languages https://t.co/j1sqTFRYEZ https://t.co/4Nky3mM3rm

Non-eurozone EU countries have made mixed progress towards meeting the necessary conditions to adopt the euro since 2018, our latest Convergence Report finds. Important steps have in particular been taken to address fiscal imbalances https://t.co/nLAyWkPRHV https://t.co/3claOE76ei

A new report on credit underwriting standards reveals weaknesses in the way banks granted new loans in 2016-18. As losses from the coronavirus crisis materialise, adequate lending standards and risk-based pricing are becoming even more important https://t.co/Q2UoLLer0Q https://t.co/4pOlvA7xdW

Time to wrap up. Thanks a lot for your questions – I really enjoyed the chat and look forward to doing it again soon. Take care! @Isabel_Schnabel #AskECB https://t.co/fZNNonEhuc
